btw, just one question..
I downloaded a different movie in .mkv format and converted it AVCHD using TSMuxer, I burn it to a DVD+R UDF 2.5..The problem is that when I play it on my Blu-Ray player the video is choppy.  But when I burn and play your .ISO, everything is working fine, the video is not choppy at all.  Do you know what can be causing this?  Or what do you use to make the movie in AVCHD format?  Thanks!

Thanks again for the awesome quality!

Hi pinoyz - TsMuxer is a fine tool, but it does not convert or encode; it simply mux's/demux's a video's file/folder structure, so unfortunately it's not that straightforward. For AVCHD to work, video resolutions need to be either 1920x1080 or 1280x780 for 1080p & 720p respectively. As you are probably aware, most movies today are aimed at theatres rather than TVs, which generally means they have an aspect ratio of 16:9/2.35:1, giving a screen resolution of around 1920x800 for 1080p, so to preserve the movie's aspect ratio, mattes/black bars have to be added to the video itself. This task alone requires a full re-encode, and without it, you will get the results that you are describing. MKV contained video files are generally cropped, so although you will still see the mattes/black bars when played via a computer's media player, they are created by the media player to fill your screen, and are not actually part of the video, which creates a problem for blu-ray players. I hope this helps.
